bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Thomas G. Clemson (1807-1888) was a South Carolina educator, diplomat, and son-in-law of John C. Calhoun. Clemson's estate funded South Carolina in the formation of Clemson College.

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: Included are an agreement between Clemson and his overseer Reuben H. Reynolds, 1848; a financial statement, 1849; a letter of introduction, 1865, for James Edward Calhoun to Max Van den Bergh, vice-consul of the United States at Antwerp, in which Clemson stated that the emancipation of slave labor would create large scale emigration of labor supply to the South; and a letter, 1870, from Anna Maria (Calhoun) Clemson concerning her family's estate.
